review_title: The best company to work as an AI researcher
pros: Meta has the smartest people and the best compute resources to train large scale AI models. The culture is very bottom up where researchers and engineers are given lots of freedom to pursue their approaches and solutions. Hiring process is setup to match candidates strengths, skills, and goals to teams. Managers don't lie about scope of work in their team in order to trick candidates to join their team. Compensation is best in the industry, perks are great. Meta truly pampers their employees. At the same time expectations are high.
cons: Given the talent in the company, even the best of people need to be on their toes and deliver. It might seem like everyone is delivering amazing results and it can become a bit stressful to keep up.

review_title: Great place if you're seeking for growth. Not a place to coast.
pros:
1. Best in class benefits. 
2. Promotions are quick for high-performers 
3. Working on big, hard, challenging problems.
cons:
1. Politics. Feels like your experience can really depend on who you are working with/for. 
2. A lot of reorgs. Unless you're good at adapting to change, it's quite tiring if you're directly impacted by it. 
3. PSC is stressful for people. There is a high bar and it's stressful trying to operate at a high bar consistently.

review_title: By far the best place I've ever worked
job_title: Software Engineering Manager in London, England
pros:
So many but:
- You get to build products that impact the daily lives of 3 billions people
- You get to be at the forefront of technology and the evolution of the internet (metaverse etc)
- Despite what the media would lead you to believe I strongly believe that Meta drives net positive good for people across the world. For example our tools and free services helped people stay connected to their loves ones during the Covid crisis. Covid lockdowns would have been significantly worse without our products.
- Strong autonomy - theres very little process and still room for individuals forge their own path
- Top of the market pay and benefits. There really are very few other alternatives employers that are able to match Meta's overall package
- Great people. Smart and humble, friendly but dedicated to their work
cons: The press cycle and current overall sentiment towards Meta (driven by the media) is a drain. It's not much fun having to defend your employer with friends and family.

pros:
Teams are great to work with, extremely welcoming, willing to give up plenty of time when you start, forthcoming with information/tips/advice and the whole environment is super collaborative.

Company is very data driven, which some might not like but I think it's great as you are able to track your performance easily without having a million separate spreadsheets.

Loads of great perks in their compensation packages, but the role itself is amazing and I am so glad I joined.
cons:
Sourcing candidates is a tough gig, lots of time goes into scrolling through LinkedIn to find the right talent that hasn't been engaged recently.
But if you're a good recruiter, this shouldn't be a problem.

pros: I've jumped around in my career and Facebook is without a doubt the best company I've ever worked at. The company culture is so supportive and empowering, and it's so refreshing to be treated like an adult. From Day 1 you're assumed  to be good at your job (as opposed to most at companies where you spend years trying to prove yourself) and your opinions are genuinely valued. It's a great place to grow and learn, and determine  your own career trajectory.
cons:
There is a lot to learn and get acclimated to when you first start. But there are so many resources and trainings that you're not left to your own devices.

Disappointed in the name change. In theory the general public know FB became Meta but they don't seem to make the connection when you say you work at Meta and it's not as impressive. I know this sounds entitled,  but I'm in recruitment and the FB name had much more sway with passive candidates.

- Really accommodating/ suportive. I felt it strongly during covid and when I had family crisis. We even have covid paid leave to sort those kind of things out. I think this is really positive for diversity and inclusion.
- Much less politics than other places I have been. The company is still in rapid growth phase and people are too busy getting stuffs done rather than fighting with each other.
- I quite like people I work with. High achievers and fast learners. And everyone is nice & collaborative possibly because the culture filters out those who are not
cons: - In many teams you are busy 4-6pm London time because of meetings with US west coast. You need to actively manage your work life balance particularly if you need to pick up kids by 6pm. WFH helps a lot. And the company/ team respects people's boundaries. For example I tell my team I need to stop at 5:30pm everyday and the US colleagues would accomodate and get up early for me.

review_title: Great Benefits and pay, bad candidate review process
pros: Meta has fantastic benefits, the most unique is 3K per year for wellness. You can use it for massages, gym memberships, golf clubs, basically anything that makes you happy.
cons: Recruiters are not involved with offer negotiation. Other than a standard offer (no ranges just preset amounts) all offers have to go through the comp team. If you enjoy negotiating offers you will not have this ability at Meta.

review_title: A lot is expected from you, but they also give you a lot
pros: Salary, benefits, multicultural environment, open and constant attention around minorities (LGBTQIA+, women, black, asian etc), innovative view, low hierarchy structure, you can grow within the company
cons:
the company move fast, you need to move fast with it. 
A lot is given to the employees so the company expects a lot in return.
Working-life balance can be challenging depending on your Manager and where your Team is based (US, Europe and/or Asia --> meeting can be quite early and/or quite late following the different time-zones). 
Performance are generally evaluated not (or not only) based on specific goals, but also based on what your colleagues from the same team on a global level have achieved compared to you (kind of benchmark performance review). So maybe your goal was X and you do X+10, but most of your teammates achieve X+30, so you can get a "doesn't meet expectations" on your review. And because of this, the environment tends to be more and more competitive (which maybe for someone can be a "pros")

review_title: Meta is an extremely great place to work
pros: Benefits, culture, work life balance
cons: Cannot think of any cons

job_title: Project Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros:
• Meta is an incredible place to gain experience, work (and network!) with people who are at the top of their fields, and grow your own skill set—IF you invest the effort and time to make it happen. 
• Many employees have the chance to work with people from all over the world, in an environment that encourages different perspectives. 
• I never thought someone like me would belong at a company like this—but I feel welcomed and encouraged, and I'm grateful to have learned so much (personally and professionally) from my coworkers. Never would've believed I'd feel this way while starting remotely during COVID, either!
• Most managers at Meta really want to be managers; folks aren't promoted just because it's the next most logical step in their career. In my experience, this means most managers are supportive, want to see you succeed, and are invested in helping you grow your career, not just in furthering their own agenda.
• Comp & benefits are amazing. WHY DID MY GUIDANCE COUNSELORS IN HIGH SCHOOL AND COLLEGE NOT TELL ME ABOUT RSUs??? That is all. 
• Having Meta on your resumé will open doors in a way that name dropping few other companies would.
• The support Meta provided throughout COVID has been exceptional, with flexibility and leave options that have helped me deal with remote learning, childcare gaps, and more. I've repeatedly told friends how lucky I have been to have joined Meta just before the pandemic.
cons:
• There are high expectations. "Move fast" isn't just a value — it's a description of how we work. If you like rigid work structures and aligning to predefined goals without questioning or re-assessing them as you progress, you probably won't thrive in the Meta environment. 
• Because of this constant flux, it can be hard to take PTO or maintain a consistently good work/life balance. This honestly depends on your team and manager, as well as how good you are at prioritizing. (Hint: Get comfortable saying no.)
• Constant press leaks continue to threaten the previously "open by default" culture, complicating some teams' jobs (as they react to announcements vs. prepare for announcements).

job_title: Data Privacy Misuse Analyst in Washington, DC
pros: Not a lot of real work.
cons: Was hired to prevent misuse of private data. It is apparent that there is no management support for this role in any form. The role was created in an attempt to fool regulators and stockholders into thinking that things are changing at facebook. The mission of facebook is to misuse private data and the role is an attempt to distract the public from that fact. I am an h1b, much like most facebook employees, and i am threatened with being booted from the program whenever i attempt to protect customer data from being exposed. If anyone from management is reading this i sincerely believe facebook is the proverbial boulder rolling down a hill with too much momentum to stop the downward slide. Metaverse is another distraction from that fact and the reviews continue to be clear: despite having great technology and facebook subsidizing every vr unit sold, adoption is declining because no one wants to sign away there privacy, for any cost.

job_title: Senior Producer in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Amazing opportunity to work on literally the biggest products in the world. Launching products to billions of people like it's no big deal. 30 million people is a "small test." 

The people are incredible smart, creative, thoughtful and collaborative. 

Amazing suite of internal tools to foster collaboration and information sharing.
cons:
It truly is a social network. Everyone wants a say in everything. People tend to guard their tiny piece of the pie zealously. Be prepared for a zillion stakeholders on everything. Executives regularly drop 11th hour feedback bombs. 

Particularly on the marketing team, strategic shifts happened every 6 months like clockwork. By the time we implemented one strategy, higher ups had already moved onto the next one. Hard to actually apply any learnings. 

With the pivot toward the metaverse, all other products will gradually take more and more of a backseat. If you're not all-in on VR, don't join Meta.

review_title: Great for a few years, tought on the long run.
pros: Working with loads of smart people is great, you learn a lot. Benefits & perks are good.
cons:
Over time there's this pressure to over perform beyond your level, with removal of bonus: there's the expectation that you should always be delivering more and more, to get the same bonus. This becomes unhearthy, as work and life balance suffers, pressure increases and you end up receiving less compensation for what's essentially the same work.

Also, there's a MASSIVE disconnect between "everything proprietary internal" and "the real world", so the longer you work for the company, the more distant you are from skills and tools that'll use at your next job, as most of what was learned, is essentially lost.

Stocks compensation also decreases with time, which is another driver to "only stay a few years".

pros:
- Good benefits 
- Ok salary
- Great office space
cons:
- shockingly bad leadership: throughout several years the global team could not decided on what are our job roles and responsibilities were. With misalignment rife throughout the org. The answer to this was constant re-orgs to help disguise the poor strategic direction from leadership. 
There was distant lack of vision/direction for the team followed by zero execution strategy.
- The team mantra was ‘ if no one is talking about our team, thats great news’. There was a culture of busy work and hiding failings
- Calibration process had nothing to do with assessing impact, but more so who liked who and who could help protect one another. You would never receive constructive feedback from the team with examples of your actions to improve - but instead you’d be served with vague and unsubstantiated statements that ‘someone’, ‘sometime’, had said that you could improve on ‘something’. No in the moment feedback or clear examples to point to and learn from (essentially making things up to fit an agenda most employees were not privy to)
- the statement of ‘bringing your authentic self to work’ often was nothing more than a collection of buzz words that had little to do with encouraging diverse opinions and constructive debate. There was the distinct sense that leadership wanted you to simply nod and smile with any idea they presented, regardless of how damaging or unthoughtful it may be. Try to challenge it in healthy/constructive/discrete and appropriate ways and you would be punished in your next calibration for your ‘poor communication skills’. 

This is to name a handful of issues. There were several more. 

I have never experienced such a toxic and unprofessional environment at a workplace. 

There seems to be a sense that top talent is now fleeing the business, leaving behind staff that simply want to collect cheques with little regard for Meta’s mission and impact on the world. It’s sad, but I feel something special has been lost over the last 5 years

review_title: Best for comp, but toxic culture nowadays
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in London, England
pros:
- Comp is above market level (although this is starting to decline)
- Chance to learn from some really awesome professionals
- Benefits are top
- Remote possibilities
cons:
- The performance feedback process (called PSC) is extremely unfair, manager decisions are not debatable and they don't need to be factual
- That means it's very easy to be bullied or harassed by the manager if they don't like you (except for protected categories); the only way out is changing team (and risk of loosing rating / set back your goals)
- Peers can also negatively effect your career with negative, undebatable feedback, that the manager will be forced to take into account lowering the ratings
- Whenever they start a new initiaive, they simply put a bunch of senior engs together and let they fight over the path to take. Most people are extremely ambitious, and happy to work 80+ hours for a chance of earning promotions/high-rating (as these are so highly compensated); they would kill each other for the chance of leading the initiative.
- This leads to a super stressful environment, where the things that count the most are long hours, politics and aggressive behaviours.
- It took me a while to realize, most people drinked the kool aid in this company
- Also YMMV, the company is huge and I can only speak by my experience and that of my circle

My advice: if you can pass the interview process without stressing to much, get in, get some money and the title in the resume, and get out; then find a more sustainable job to settle with. My understanding is that most people is doing exactly that @ Meta. Personally though, I don't feel it's not worth it.

pros:
- The people! I get to work with interesting, motivated, and passionate people every day. Our differences are celebrated, and I appreciate that I can be my true, authentic self. 
- The health & wellness benefits are exceptional. Flexible work - I am excited to have the option to work fully remote! 
- So much potential for real impact - it isn't top-down leadership here, so there is a lot of opportunity to find projects, present ideas, stretch & grow my career .
cons: We work hard - really hard. It is important to be extremely organized and prioritize ruthlessly. Everything moves fast and there are always a lot of changes. This is both a pro & a con - I like that we are always working to improve, but in order to be successful here, a person has to be able to move fast, learn & adapt quickly, and embrace changes. It is exciting - it can also be overwhelming & can mean some looong days.

Ended up leaving for another company which paid me much more.

Also, lots of negative press surrounding the company's scandals.

review_title: I love coming to work everyday
pros:
- Impactful work - It is amazing having the opportunity to do work that has direct impact to the company and the community. Not only does this make the work rewarding, but it keeps the day-to-day aspects of the job exciting. 

- Feedback and Transparency - We have a very open and transparent culture here. This allows us to work quickly and efficiently. Being able to drive important conversations with each other has been key in driving healthy collaboration and workplace relationships. 

- Employee Value - FB Leadership really values their employees. This is demonstrated not only through all of the amazing benefits and work; but also the care and thought that goes into making Facebook and our work culture healthy and exciting. At the end of the day, I feel valued as an employee which makes me show up to work each day wanting to work hard and make positive impact for the people we build products for and the company itself.
cons:
Large public companies always seem to be in the spotlight. There are always criticisms that pop up and sometimes it can be challenging responding to questions from family or friends about something they saw in the news. 
But at the end of the day, Facebook employees are driven by our mission. Products are not perfect, but we're always open to feedback to figure out how we can continually improve our company and products.

job_title: Production Engineer in Menlo Park, CA
pros:
* Smart people who take their jobs seriously (well they don't want to lose their job!)
* Most of them are friendly and respectful enough despite you may disagree with them politically or culturally or on work matters
* Extremely good amenities, perks and compensation. Google is the only one that can match FB on most perks
* Pretty much everything is built in-house. so there is some way to get people help you/fix bugs instead of bugging an open source community which may never want you patch
cons:
* WLB is not great if you come in not knowing a particular language, say, C++, because debugging through any codebase can be very tough
* Many things to fix at FB, so you will be easily distracted and can put risks on achieving impacts on your primary goals for the half
* While in-house tools are great from a "please fix it" approach, it's also usually come at the cost of usability and stability. We really could use more help in making tooling accessible and useful
* Impacts is go big or go home. Everyone is obsessed and measured by impacts. This could be cpu win or engagement metric move or power reduction or productivity. But ultimately we are chasing the big stuff in the name of promotion, and forget we need to grind through the small stuff that are actually most important to a healthier WLB and relaibility.

The upper management actually cares about making the world a better place. And everyone is trying their best to do good and ethical things. I really enjoy the smart and empathetic people that I work with.
cons: I would say the main negative at FB is also a positive. Much of the way FB works is driven from the bottom up. On the positive side, everyone has a lot of say in the work that they do and the impact that they have. On the negative side, it sometimes seems like it is hard to move very fast without better top-down organization. You have to be able to tolerate a fair amount of uncertainty when you work here.

pros:
- Benefits: unparalleled. Free therapy, food, gym, wellness stipends, endless discounts, great healthcare.
- Comp: pays top dollar for attracting talent.
- People: smartest people in the game, incredible talent. If you're working on something new, chances are there's someone else at the company who has worked on something similar and is willing to help you. People generally have good intentions and are pretty easy to work with. 
- Offices: amazing workspaces 
- Autonomy: if you want to work on something, raise your hand and you will often get the thumbs up to do what you want. Very few micromanagers that I've seen.
cons:
- Difficult work environment: lots of pressure to perform and show "impact". Ironically, this creates a highly competitive culture internally and results in a lack of meaningful impact. Dealing with internal politics and alignment with other teams is more than half the job. There are many, many smart people with redundant roles- which results in duplicative work and inefficiency. This job is about how well you sell your work internally, not the results you achieve or impact you have on your audience. I've observed people do the bare minimum and spend 80% of their time on internal PR (this works!). Be prepared to work with 30+ cross functional partners on a project.
- Culture: this varies greatly by team, but in my experience- many people have joined Meta for the comp and benefits, and are not aligned with the mission or direction leadership is taking the company. Many people are burned out and do the bare minimum to maintain their job security. The people who do raise their hands to take on extra work are not acknowledged or rewarded in review cycles. Instead they are seen as the go-to people for all the miscellaneous stuff. After a while, nobody volunteers to take on anything outside their job descriptions, because there is zero incentive to do so. 
- For a B2B marketing org, Meta is not very data-driven. Lack of SE/DE/analysts mean that it is very difficult to get internal dashboards built and maintained in a timely fashion. Everything has to be built from scratch at Meta, which results in very slow moving launches and launch results. Years away from being an agile marketing org.
- Career growth: very slow and lots of ambiguity for how to get to the next level. Expect to be in your role with the roughly the same comp and equity for about 3-4 years (even if you are exceeding expectations).

pros:
Benefits
They tend to offer reasonable benefits packages. They will likely offer you everything you are looking for in terms of benefits and more. You will likely be taken care of in that way. 

Networking
The layout and structure of the Meta buildings is set up in a way that you have the opportunity to run into just about anyone who works there. There are social events happening very often that give you the opportunity to meet people who you may not have ever worked with in your tenure and make meaningful connections.

ERGs/Clubs
I strongly encourage getting involved with these internal organizations. Your success at this company will have a lot to do with who knows you and is therefore advocating for you during employee evaluations. These organizations will keep you sane and give you an outlet while providing some balance with your work.
cons:
Not true autonomy
I joined the company thinking that I was being hired to bring my unique talents to the table and it returns out that was not true. In my experience, the company wants more people like they already have that worked there. This bothered me a lot as I found it difficult to assimilate to the ways of thinking and reaching our organizational goals without trying something different which the organization was not willing to hear. 

Little to NO work Life Balance
The company provides more amenities than any employee can use at any time. This is great if you have the time to use them. Most people eat, workout, play sports, play games, socialize, attend events, and network AT ALL WORK. And even when they are at home or on vacation they are still working to prove that they are dedicated to the company. There are many spoken rules to the access they have to you at this company, meaning that you will be at their disposal at any point they need you. If you are not, you will be punished. Not overtly, but certainly covertly. The company standards do not allow you to maintain healthy boundaries for yourself and I don’t think it is their intent to do that either. 

Difficult Internal Mobility
When I was hired, I was led to believe that internal mobility was easy. You can look up jobs available internally and talk to the folks hiring. Obviously, there is no guarantee that you will get the job that you want but you may have a slight advantage. Here, the company operates like many small companies within the same walls. There is no advantage. In fact, it may feel like you are under the microscope even more so coming from within the company. It is a weird and honestly icky feeling. I found this out when I wanted to do the same role in an adjacent department.


Don’t Always Practice Values
The company’s values have changed a bit to fit more of what the company wants from employees. Unfortunately, these values are weaponized from employee to employee. This makes the work environment hostile. If you say something to your manager, skip level manager, or coworker that they don’t agree with or don’t want to hear, the company’s values may be used as a response to dismiss, demean, and invalidate your perspective in the conversation. This made it nearly impossible to make changes where they desperately needed to be made in my work.

great benefits, but keep in mind other companies also offer great benefits
large name brand on resume
few but some great leaders
cons:
If you are a person of color, I will save you the time. Your time and effort in your job search will be better spent elsewhere. In the sales organization (other groups report better experiences) people are treated well according to their race - mini me syndrome is rampant from leadership. 
The BIPOC allys who were great leaders have left or plan to leave. During my time, I experienced a lot of willful ignorance and insulting false promises towards BIPOC people, with Black people being treated the worst - inappropriately toxic. Since the company isn't doing well in many areas, they are trying to hold themselves to DEI hiring goals without doing the work to do better. Many turn a blind eye to the issues yet talk about it in private rooms. Some people having misguided conversations about DEI having never had to think about it in their lives prior to BLM 2020. 
When I resigned, multiple people reached out to me asking me to take them with me, telling me openly they were out the door as well as soon as more money came along.
Do not be fooled by the lip service. Go where you will grow, be promoted and acknowledged in all of your amazing talent. Too many horror stories to name here but many articles out there about the Black experience , as well as others, that I now know to be true. Do not be fooled, it is a rare occasion that working in the Meta sales org will mean career growth if you're Black or Brown - eventually you will find yourself on the hunt again. I could go on and on.

review_title: Used to be great, increasingly corporate
pros: They pay for your immigration.
cons:
The key to success in Operations at Facebook is to be liked by your manager. If they like you, you'll have no problem getting promoted regardless of your work. I've been told by multiple managers in Ops that they care more about how someone gets things done than what their actual impact is (read: how much people like you) - even though the company line is that your performance is measured based on your impact.

If your manager doesn't like you, they'll break you down to the point that you can't trust your own decisions and then give you critical feedback for asking them for help with decision making.

The messaging they give to individual contributors (ICs) is that performance is measured against an impartial expectations grid, but what actually happens is that the managers get together to compare their reports and rank them, so the way your performance is measured changes with each review cycle. The documentation they provide managers also ties promotions to things like tenure, even though the documentation they give to ICs says that it's based on the expectations grid.

pros: Great place to work at

review_title: Make big money, but very little [real] impact
pros:
- Compensation is way better than most (non-tech) companies in London
- Great benefits
- Nice offices
- Some great people (who probably won't stay long)
- Fast paced nature means that you'll likely learn a lot in a short amount of time
- If you drink the Kool-Aid, you can grind your way to promotions and more money
cons:
- Compared to US offices, your pay is going to feel like a total joke, even though you're living in a city with a similar COL. 

- I found a lot of people had a an immature outlook that focused on their own assumptions about the product experience and personal views/agendas rather than real user needs. 

- Lots of lip service about wanting to improve the experience of our users, but really a huge focus on moving metrics. Did not feel like my team genuinely cared about fixing pain points and making peoples' lives easier.

- So much rung climbing and self-promotion drove me crazy. Everything about making posts and endless chats and putting together documentation to "prove" that you're doing something for performance review time.

- Performance review culture focused on demonstrating metric based impact led to poor decision making for short term "wins" (often to the detriment of the user experience)

- Can be pretty terrible WLB depending on your team and how much interaction you might have with teams in different time zones.

- Collaboration not always great. Felt like different teams didn't really talk to each other when it mattered, and the same work was being done over and over again. But hey, what does it matter when you're incentivised to put out as many docs/posts as possible to prove your 'impact'?

- Non-Eng or non PM roles can feel like you're treated as an afterthought.

- Surprisingly backstab-y/cliquey behaviour among some leads that left a really bad taste in my mouth. When you're singling out individuals to try and save yourselves from taking responsibility for criticism (lack of inclusion, poor wlb), that's a sign you should actually be introspective and try and help resolve employee complaints.

- Debatable as to whether the company is even producing anything that's a net positive to society anymore. :(

pros:
I have not learned or grown more on any other job more than I have at Facebook. If you do your best work in a fast paced, performance-driven environment - Facebook is the place for you.

- Reward is proportionate to impact. You will move up fast if you can meet the high bar for performance.
- Performance processes are designed to be objective - so there is very little room for bias or discrimination.
- Highly collaborative culture
- Excellent internal tools
- Excellent benefits
- Lots of flexibility for defining your own growth path.
cons:
- A small group of vocal employees are creating a lot of internal pressure for more and more speech censorship on the platform.
- Not all managers / teams are great. You need to choose your team carefully when you join.
- You'll have to swear an oath of allegiance to hard-left progressive faith, or your life will be very difficult.
- Poor work-life balance.
- Frequent reorgs.
- Frequent shift in direction.

review_title: Great benefits, pay, and a real effort to make FB a fantastic place to work.
pros:
Benefits:

1. So far FB has given 5 extra PTOish days off this year to help folks relax and recharge.
2. Thanksgiving week off last year.
3. Remote work for pretty much all employees (if desired).
4. Comp is high.

Actual Work:

1. FB has some amount of the bureaucracy you'd expect to find at a large company but I think it is much better than other companies I have worked at. In my experience you have a lot of autonomy in shaping what you work on and finding teams / projects that fit your career goals.
2. Reasonably efficient dev infrastructure makes a lot of my job pretty painless. That might be more contentious as others have expressed they feel differently.
3. Working on stuff that is used by billions of people is interesting and satisfying.
cons:
Benefits:

1. A higher match (>4%) for the 401k would be nice.

Actual Work:

1. Some people dislike the bad press that the company gets. I personally don't care but for some I think it can be taxing.
2. It is a very growth oriented company. In my opinion this leads to a lot of tech debt and developer overhead for certain tasks. I cannot speak for everyone on this however.

review_title: Bad direction, no critical feedback of first-time managers
pros:
Overall compensation
Top tech kit
Some areas are very promising
cons:
When joining, I picked Shops because it was a promising project, but after I made my decision, it was clear that the Org was notoriously disorganised. The project has lost most of its key personnel because the Director for Product was unable to give a clear direction, and censored all the reasonable ideas. My manager was inexperienced and refused to hear any suggestion that I made. It felt really demoralising and frustrating. I reached out to other managers, friends from previous job who agreed that it was frustrating… but that’s it.
– I agree, this is a horrible situation.
– What can I do about it?
– I don’t know…
– Wait a year, so I can change teams?
– Maybe. That was changed to 18 months though.

All three of the Org, the project and my manager had "the worst Pulse rating in the history of the company" at their level, according to people who had been at Facebook longer. No one reached out.

Several key stakeholders left, notably one senior Data engineer. I offered to take over some of their workload because I knew how and I badly needed data to do my own work. That was yet another suggestion that my manager shut down.

It got tiring really fast.

pros: Great pay and great benefits, teamwork atmosphere.
cons: Marketing at Facebook in general is 10 years behind the curve. We don't have reliable marketing automation tools and functionality so your ability to be strategic, creative, and drive massive impact is hindered. For example, we don't have the ability to send real-time emails based upon advertiser browsing behavior or engagement, we don't do lead scoring, and we have zero insight into what comms our audience is receiving from any given marketing team at Facebook. Promotion is very challenging as well because we have very bottom heavy with IC's and very heavy on the director level. It's sad to say but I have been at Facebook 3+ years and have seen little to no change in the way we do marketing.

review_title: Show more Empathy towards employees based outside of the US
pros: Great career progression opportunities, interesting work, great TC and benefits
cons:
Facebook is incredibly inflexible when it comes to working from abroad (we are limited to max 10 days of work outside our country of employment). This puts many employees in a difficult situation during the pandemic as we can rarely see our families/partners (especially given the complicated 2 weeks quarantine in many countries in Europe). This is extremely harmful for many people's mental health and does not make much sense from a legal perspective either. 

Other companies like Microsoft, Stripe, Google, etc. have no such limitation at the moment. We're not liable for taxes if we're not residents of the countries we want to temporarily work out of, and residency starts at ~180d for the year in most countries. There's very little time difference between countries in Europe and many of us could easily do their jobs from other countries in the EU while our main office is closed (within the 6 months legal limit). HR simply doesn't seem to care about this as the US workforce is not impacted (they can work from anywhere in the US despite greater differences in the time zone). 

I really hope FB will start showing empathy towards people who are separated from their loved ones and will extend the policy to more than 10 days a year.

Technical skill is a given (and yes, if you got in, that is taken for granted -- stop thinking you're not good enough ;) ), but what astonished me was the way that entire teams worked together in a meta way to improve their dynamics.
cons: It wasn't always sunshine and rainbows -- expectations are clear and intense, and when you're falling behind, it's incredibly stressful. Furthermore, the entire company is beholden to the ads department for funding, and that department alone is responsible for an unbelievable amount of social and psychological problems in our modern world. Therefore, any work you do feels like you're chipping away at the integrity of the world and of yourself (unless you're one of the lucky few who work on teams dedicated to addressing the systemic issues big tech causes).

job_title: Senior Research Manager in Menlo Park, CA
pros: High bar for talent (you learn by your peers), makes/keeps you sharp, rational/data-driven culture, VERY people oriented, great total comp and benefits. Have more respect for Zuck since having worked here; seems candid and earnest in bettering the company's outlook. Lots of interesting product development happening consistently.
cons: Productivity suite is chaotic / not standardized across teams (takes a lot of time managing personal comms), sometimes it can feel TOO people oriented (very surprising what can be said to managers and Zuck himself that is honestly flat out disrespectful but tolerated...also, lots of entitlement - particularly at lower levels that can make managing teams/talent tiresome). For mid-career professionals (L5-L6 in particular), advancement is tougher as the company gets bigger/evolves; seems like there are more growth opportunities for junior levels (in terms of promo: L2/L3) and senior levels (in terms of new areas of learning/expansion: L8/D1+). For SOME people, the high ambiguity, fast pace, and 99% self-determination of one's career will not fit their personal preferences. For me personally, it works well. But I have friends at the company who are quite frustrated/unhappy due to the lack of tops-down order and seemingly chaotic shifting of priorities and strategies. (Note: I work in Facebook Reality Labs, which is definitely more nascent and a bit different in flavor than the 'core apps' teams.)

review_title: Your experience depends on your manager
pros: Great benefits, competitive compensation and yearly equity refreshers.
cons: Performance review process is a nightmare and can feel like trying to hit a moving target while blindfolded at times. It leaves much room for favoritism, discrimination and can vary widely depending on your manager. Also company also talks a lot about “work-life balance” but doesn’t really do anything concrete to create a working environment to do so, specifically for those who struggle with mental health. That said, they sure love to talk about it like they mean it. They don’t.

cons: After a while, even if you do well, the communication gets stifled, lines get cut, and eventually you'll be on the chopping board through no fault of your own.
